METS:xmlData.entity:description: Po obsegu ozemlja je bil zemljevid Napoleonovega cesarstva iz leta 1812 presenetljivo podoben zemljevidu zgodnje povojne Evrope po Rimski pogodbi iz leta 1957. Je šlo za naključje? V obdobju evropske zgodovine med leti 1772 in 1815/30 je prišlo do velikih sprememb in premikanja mej, kakršnega v zgodovini še ni bilo. Republika obeh narodov (zveza Kraljevine Poljske in Velike litovske kneževine) je razpadla, Napoleonovo cesarstvo se je hitro širilo, Sveto rimsko cesarstvo pa se je po letu 1815 umaknilo novo oblikovani Srednji Evropi: Nemški zvezi. Spremembe ozemelj (ali bolje rečeno revolucija) so bile posledica Francoske revolucije, ki je povzročila trk ideologij, skoraj dve desetletji vojne, hkrati pa tudi drugačne zamisli o teritorialnosti. Nekatere ozemeljske spremembe, na primer delitve Republike obeh narodov, so bile dolgoročne. Druge, na primer širitev Francoskega cesarstva, pa niso trajale prav dolgo. Zdi se, da je Dunajski kongres do neke mere ponovno vzpostavil ozemeljski red izpred leta 1789 skupaj s porazdelitvijo "ravnovesja moči". Zadevno obdobje je bilo pogosto analizirano z vidika revolucije, vojne, diplomacije, konfliktov in (pre)razporeditve moči. Vendar pa je bilo to tudi obdobje globokih vezi, neprimerljivih premikov ljudi in celo sodelovanja. V prispevku bom skušal slediti dediščini tega obdobja in "fantomskim mejam", ki jih je to obdobje ustvarilo. Po splošnem pregledu se bom posvetil natančnejši analizi pravne dediščine in gospodarskega sodelovanja po letu 1815. Nova fantomska meja, ki je nastala v mentalnem zemljevidu avtorjev in popotnikov okrog leta 1830/40, je meja med "Vzhodno" in "Zahodno" Evropo. Konstrukcija evropskega Vzhoda in Zahoda ni bila samo mentalna, prav tako pa ni šlo samo za razlikovanje od "drugih". V sami "Zahodni Evropi" pa lahko ob (novih povojnih) ozemeljskih mejah Nizozemske, nemških dežel, Belgije in Francije opazimo tudi vzpostavitev jedra (integriranega) mejnega ozemlja. Skupno izkoriščanje rudnika cinka, zajezitev voda, izgradnja infrastrukture, "prostorsko preživetje", zapuščina civilnega zakonika, kasneje pa tudi uporaba Esperanta kažejo na izoblikovanje jedra "Zahodne Evrope", internacionalizem in sanje o Evropi brez meja. O tem je nekoč sanjal Napoleon. Se je jedro gibanja Esperanto naključno vzpostavilo v centru že zdavnaj izginule notranjosti Napoleonovega cesarstva? Bi cesar sam sprejel Esperanto in se jezika naučil, ko je prišel do Rena?

In terms of their territorial reach, the map of the Napoleonic empire of 1812 looks surprisingly similar to that of the early postwar Europe, that of the Treaty of Rome in 1957. An accident? The period of European history between 1772 and 1815/30 has seen dramatic and indeed unprecedented territorial revisions and shifting borders. The Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth was partitioned, the Napoleonic Empire expanded rapidly, the Holy Roman Empire gave way to a newly structured Central Europe, namely the German Confederation after 1815. The territorial revisions (or rather revolution) were part and parcel of the French Revolution, that ushered into the clash of ideologies, almost two decades of warfare, but also different ideas of territoriality. Some of the territorial changes were long-term, such as the partitions of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. Others, such as the expansion of the French Empire, were rather short-lived. To some extent, it seems, the Congress of Vienna reestablished a territorial order of pre-1789 along the lines of a “balance of power”. The period under investigation has often been analysed through the lens of revolution, warfare, diplomacy, conflict, and (re)balance of power. The same period, however, was also one of deep entanglements, unprecedented movement of people, and even cooperation. In this contribution I try to trace some of the legacies of this period and the “phantom borders” it created by moving from a macroscopic birds-eye-view to a more microscopic analysis of legal legacies and economic cooperation post 1815. One new phantom border that emerged on the mental map of authors or travellers around 1830/40 that between “East” and “West” Europe. The construction of Europe East & West was not only a mental one and not exclusively one of “othering”. Within “Western Europe” itself, along the (new, postwar) territorial borders of the Netherlands, the German Lands, Belgium, and France we see the emergence of a nucleus of an (integrated) borderland. By the shared use of a zink mine, the taming of water, the building of infrastructure, the “spatial survival” and legacy of the Code Civil, and (later) the use of Esperanto we may also see the emergence of a nucleus “Western Europe”, internationalism, and the dream of a borderless Europe. A dream (once) dreamt by Napoléon. Was it by accident that the stronghold of the Esperanto movement was at the core of the long gone Napoleonic (inner) empire? Would the Emperor himself have embraced and learned Esperanto once it came to the Rhine?
